thread.title: Darwin, the tropical city luring in young professionals from across Australia
thread.title_full: Darwin, the tropical city luring in young professionals from across Australia

title: Darwin, the tropical city luring in young professionals from across Australia

organizations.name: top end association for mental health

text:
Darwin, the tropical city luring in young professionals from across Australia Kate Burke NT a beacon for young professionals Graduates are flocking to the Northern Territory to get a few years experience and a leg-up in their industries. The last areas Sydney first-home buyers can afford Sydneysider Neha Chopra had never been to Darwin before she decided to uproot her life and move to Australia’s northernmost capital city. 
The 25-year-old was sceptical when she chose to leave behind her family, friends and job offers in Sydney for the “perfect” graduate policy role with the Northern Territory government. But that was more than a year ago and she hasn’t looked back since. 
“I was actually hesitant because I did a lot of researching beforehand and I was like ‘wow this place sounds really different’,” Neha told Domain. 
Sydneysider Neha Chopra moved to Darwin to take up a graduate role with the NT government and hasn’t looked back since. Photo: Shannon Ruddock 
While Darwin’s outdoor and laid-back lifestyle, proximity to national parks and multicultural community make the city an attractive place to live, it’s the career opportunities that are surprisingly drawing in an unlikely crowd of young professionals from big cities like Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth. 
Neha, like many others young professionals leaving capital cities down south, sees Darwin as a strategic stepping stone for her career. 
“I do love it here, but I feel like Darwin is a great place for career advancement,” Neha, a policy graduate with the Department of Trade, Business and Innovation said. “I think I’ll stay here for a few years, really enjoy it and see where it takes me from there.” 
Young professionals are moving to Darwin from right across Australia to take up career opportunities. Photo: Tourism NT. 
It is this trend that has informed Darwin’s highly transient population and has created a unique community, according to Charles Darwin University senior research fellow Andrew Taylor . 
“That happens a lot and is what we call escalated migration, where people are escalating their careers by doing a stint up in Darwin,” Dr Taylor said. “In might be a year or two years and they can jump a lot of levels when they get back home.” 
It’s a trend that permeates onto the streets. Look around and you’ll find that trendy cafes and small bars are popping up in the city more frequently, while Darwin’s larger iconic venues still manage to lure in big crowds of young backpackers and professionals. 
Neha Chopra believes that Darwin is a great place for career advancement. Photo: Shannon Ruddock. 
Data from the ABS also shows that Greater Darwin has a median age of 33.3, the youngest of any capital city and well below the national median of 37.4, according to data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics . 
The city’s younger median population is due to the fact that many young professionals from interstate return home when they decide to settle down, according to Dr Taylor. 
He said other factors affecting the median age include the prevalence of industries like construction and the defence force, which are dominated by young males, the seasonal influx of backpackers, the limited number of people who retire in Darwin and sadly, the fact that Indigenous people, who make up about 10 per cent of the population, have a shorter life expectancy. 
Darwin has the youngest median population of all the capital cities. Photo: Tourism NT. 
Of the 142,300 people living in Greater Darwin in June 2015, an estimated 7 per cent (10,044) had only moved to Darwin from other states and territories within the previous year, more than half of whom came from other greater capital city areas, according to ABS data. 
By comparison, only 0.8 per cent (40,981) of Sydney’s 4,921,000 population in June 2015, were estimated to have migrated from other states and territories in the previous year. 
Young professionals, such as Dr Robert Tait are lured to Darwin by job opportunities, but also the chance for adventure. Photo: Shannon Ruddock. 
Dr Taylor noted that apart from the appeal of less competition for job opportunities, young professionals were drawn to Darwin because it offered higher wages, the opportunity to engage with Indigenous culture, a multicultural community, proximity to south-east Asia, a warm climate and the chance to explore the outback. 
“It’s like this frontier place for young people … They can come and have a good time, then if it all gets too much, too hot, or they don’t like their job you can go back home.” 
Katy Moir is another young gun who moved up to Darwin two years ago to work for the highly regarded architecture firm Troppo. 
“A lot of people do feel like they are only going to be here for two years, so they’re very motivated about getting out to see those prime spots,” said Katy, a recent architecture graduate from Brisbane. 
Graduate of Architecture Katy Moir loves the Darwin lifestyle. Photo: Shannon Ruddock. “A lot of your life revolves around planning trips, you’re always already thinking of long weekends and big breaks, in terms of how far can we get and what can we see in that time.” 
Katy has much more responsibility at work than she believes she would have been offered in Brisbane where she studied, but said career progression quickly became a “bonus” to her new life in Darwin. 
The 29-year-old said the ever-changing population meant there was a unique sense of camaraderie in Darwin, that you didn’t find in other cities, and joked that it was helped along by the monsoon which “breaks people, in a nice way” and helps remove social barriers that you can’t have when it’s that hot. 
“With Darwin basically because it is so transient, most people have either experienced being the new person here or experienced having lots of new people coming and so everyone sort of understands what it feels like so people are very keen to meet you and help you settle in,” she said. 
“But also there is that aspect that you’re kind of losing a friend every six months … but you just have to roll with those punches.” Tough challenges for Darwin 
The transient population is also hard on the city itself. 
The high turnover of people makes economic development difficult as businesses are constantly having to find and retrain staff, according to Dr Taylor, who also noted the city attracted more men than women, due to job opportunities in male-dominated industries like defence and construction, resulting in a gender imbalance. 
Greater Darwin was the only capital city in the year to June 2015, where males outnumbered females, with the latest ABS data on sex ratios showing there are 110.8 males for every 100 females. 
“The government of all levels desperately want people to stay longer,” Dr Taylor said. “They’re very conscious of trying to retain people, particularly young professionals, who might have a family and contribute to the population further, they do try and encourage this.” 
The Northern Territory government rolled out a first home owner program in October, which gives stamp duty concessions and renovation grants to first home buyers who purchase existing homes, to help encourage migration. It also has a worker attraction program, which matched workers from Launceston, Wollongong, Adelaide and Melbourne in 2016, with in-demand jobs in the Northern Territory. 
The Lord Mayor of Darwin, Katrina Fong Lim, said she hoped more young professionals would be tempted to make Darwin their permanent home. 
The Lord Mayor of the City of Darwin Katrina Fong Lim said the biggest challenge for the city was being able to offer the same level of infrastructure and facilities as other capital cities, while creating a welcoming community. 
“The city doesn’t have a dedicated program, but vision of offering a tropical city that is liveable and offering choice, to attract young people to stay and to have their families here,” she said. 
“ A highly transient population can create a situation where people are not necessarily connected to the community … as we are so young, we focus on making it social community, there are so many festivals and outdoor events, the outdoor lifestyle is attractive to a lot of young professionals and does create the opportunity for them to form connections.” 
After completing his helicopter training, Roy Smith decided to leave Sydney behind to pursue work in central Queensland, before moving to Darwin to fly for Airborne Solutions. Photo: Shannon Ruddock An unconventional life in Darwin 
Helicopter pilot Roy Smith, who moved to Darwin five months ago, thinks it is a great place for young people with an adventurous spirit to cut their teeth in their chosen industry. 
While Roy’s move to Darwin was a matter of taking what work he could find as a recently qualified pilot, he is relishing the chance to hone his skills through a variety of flying opportunities he said he wouldn’t get to experience in other capital cities. 
“We do a lot of tourist work up here … in the bigger cities that is generally quite straight forward, you do lots of laps or circuits … Darwin is surrounded by bushland, so we do a lot of bush flying … we fly people out to remote outback pubs, fly them out to Kakadu … to secret remote (fishing) spots you can only get to by helicopter.” 
“My favourite place that I fly to would have to be Kakadu especially during the wet season, there’s just spectacular waterfalls … and the wildlife out there is really fantastic.” 
Kakadu National Park is Roy Smith’s favourite place to fly. Photo: Glenn Campbell 
The same goes for Kylie Ella, a mental health promotions manager for Top End Association for Mental Health , and her fiance Robbie Tait, a paediatrician.They both get to work in remote Indigenous communities, which wasn’t a possibility when they lived in Sydney. 
“When we do go out it’s a great experience, it really is so beautiful,” said Kylie, who noted she had never had a better or more rewarding role than she does now. 
Moving to Darwin had given both Kylie Ella and her fiance Robbie Tait the chance to work in remote Indigenous communities. Photo: Shannon Ruddock. 
“It’s been fantastic,” she added. “When I came to Darwin, I applied for a job that seemed like my ideal job, and I got it, whereas in Sydney it would be so difficult to even get an interview.” 
Dr Tait said it was a privilege to visit remote communities and experience Indigenous culture, but noted it was sad to see that “third world diseases” such as rheumatic heart disease, malnutrition and failure to thrive, were still a major problem in the Northern Territory. 
Demand for paediatricians in the top end, has led Dr Tait to work in both the private and public health systems, and enabled him to set up his private practice Darwin Paediatrics, something he believes would have been harder to do in other capital cities. 
Dr Robert Tait enjoys the variety of work he is able to do up in Darwin. Photo: Shannon Ruddock. 
Another big part of Darwin’s appeal for the couple, who got engaged at a waterfall in Litchfield National Park, is the outdoor adventure and activities that come with living in Darwin. 
“People that come to Darwin like the outdoors, they like swimming, they like hiking, they like fishing, and during the dry season they love getting out at night,” Dr Tait said.
